comments.commentBody:
Supporters of the death penalty [DP] argue that in order to execute all vicious
criminals we must accept the risk of executing innocent people.
Opponents of DP [I am one.] believe the non- zero risk of executing an innocent person, means that the DP must be abolished even if some vicious criminals escape DP.
Criminals escaping DP does NOT mean they are set free just that instead of being executed they are imprisoned for life without parole.
How large is this risk of executing an innocent person..
In her book, “Orange is the new Black” author, Piper Kerman quotes Innocence Project statistics.
She writes “ Since 1992 more than 250 innocent people have been exonerated thru DNA testing (which is available in only a small fraction of cases) including 17 who were at one time sentenced to death.”
*****
My comments:
Since DNA is available in a small number of cases the number falsely convicted and sentenced to death is considerably higher than the numbers Kerman cites.

Ah yes, sports as the new opiate of the people. And now, what, I'm supposed to feel good about our Department of Justice? Relentless in its crackdown of this soccer organization? Pursue the big bankers, and I'll feel like my tax money is being put to good use. And if the federal government were to start regulating those bribes known as political contributions, I'd take its efforts seriously.

Ahhhhh.
If true, I like. A lot.
And the NFL is next? I'm praying.

Absolutely agree.
Why can we not arrest the corrupt bankers like this?
In every country?

I find that a bizarre argument, yet I keep reading it on multiple blogs.

The reason why these arrests happen now is because they only can happen now. All officials in one location (once a year). And they send a strong message to those not yet indicted.

In any event, the one nation one vote system (regardless of how many people play soccer in that nation or what quality the game has in those nations) is the base for such corruption. Imagine someone from Nepal accepting $ 5m in bribes for his vote. Where people live on $5 / day.
Then how do you justify capital punishment for the murder of a law enforcement officer but not for the murder of a shop keeper?

I don't see what laws have been broken. These are professional athletes, who play for an organization that operates by its own rules.  Who cares how they conduct business or decides who gets paid?  Am I missing something here? Please enlighten me.
I recommended your article - except it is mostly US reader who are complaining about this prosecution.
My gut tells me only this: there is something much deeper going on here—and it's much more than football.
What does soccer being a minor sport in this country have to do with fraud and corruption being committed? A crime is crime regardless of whether soccer is popular or not. There is no connection.

Why is the US going to prosecute FIFA executives when soccer is a minor sport in this country? Shouldn't we leave this to countries which are truly involved in this sport? How can the US have another government arrest these people when they committed their crimes elsewhere.
This is a total waste of time and resources. Our attorney general has far more important cases to prosecute. Our national sports engage in monopolies and covert agreements with cities. How else could teams which make huge sums of money get the taxpayers of the host cities to pay for huge stadiums so the owners can make even more money at our expense. That is racketeering. Let the rest of the world worry about the corruption in soccer and let us clean up our own sports first.
This is a complete overstepping of her authority, while ignoring illegal activity in the US. This is an embarrassment for the US. We can't win a war on the battlefield so we make one in the court room instead. What a massive waste of taxpayer dollars!

I think Mr. Liao's comments were very illuminating.  To fixate on the headline is a clever way for the commenter to distract from the facts - Xi will eliminate his opposition by all means possible without respect to the people's welfare.
Yeah, cause you guys did such a great job dealing with FIFA's crooks without us...

I don't doubt that FIFA is rife with corruption. But it seems very out of place for the US to prosecute foreigners on foreign soil for corruption when the DOJ still hasn't prosecuted any bankers that crashed the world economy. Something stinks worse here than FIFA corruption.

It would be interesting to see the EU prosecute and extradite NFL executives for corruption, or better yet some of those corrupt Wall Street bankers that not only got away with millions and no jail time, but got multi-million dollar bonuses after the US taxpayers bailed out the too big to fail banks.

Some of the responses to Paula's article are so angry, it makes me wonder what those readers are dealing with in their own lives.  I didn't really experience the devastation of alcoholism until well into middle age when I tried to help an in-law who was struggling with a dual diagnosis of alcoholism and bipolar disorder.  In spite of my caring and sympathy, and my attempt not to be judgmental, I saw firsthand the destruction that comes with the disease.  Attempts to comfort were met with paranoia and anger.  A poem I shared that had at times given me peace in times of anxiety or anguish....as much a prayer as a poem....was taken by her as an attack.  She was so angry.  She was irrational. She was mean.  And so sad.  She is still drinking, but seems to be doing better...I don't really know because openness is not a quality of most alcoholics.  All the hurtful, vindictive words she hurled at me she has conveniently forgotten.  Yet I continue to care for her, and wish her well.  Fortunately, for me, I live diagonally across the country from her and do not have to deal with the day in/day out chaos of life with an alcoholic.  Anyway, my heart goes to Paula.  I understand why she has chosen to write honestly about what it was like with her husband.  I assume that while he was still alive she did what my in-law's husband and siblings and friends have always done, which is to pretend life is not miserable, and that there is a semblance of normal.

While I agree about Lance Armstrong and also the Banksters, one prosecution should not be compared against another. This has been a long investigation against Miami based CONCAF and also against Chuck Blazer, a US citizen.

Martin,

I'll figure out the puzzle connection tomorrow. I'm still celebrating the Hawks win.
Protestants and Catholics killing one another?  Absolutely never happens.  Certainly not in Croatia.  Or Bosnia.  Or Northern Ireland.  Or...

It has nothing to do with the game. The case is right there in front of us. The FBI is after illegal practices that go against financial rules and sport ethics, in addition to that the US bid for the World Cup and it has the right to pursue an organization that has become synonymous with corruption. FIFA is a hodgepodge and its great the US is leading on what most countries would probably be bribed one way or another
Is anyone really surprised that FIFA is rife w/corruption?  Check out the Olympics - same thing.  Doesn't our AG have any domestic criminals to bring to justice?

Math? The operative number here is 2018 - the year for which Russia was selected to be the host of the World Cup. The sanctions were ramped up starting on March 20th 2014, see:

http://www.treasury.gov/resource-center/sanctions/Programs/Documents/eo1...

That's 4 years before 2018 - do you think that maybe, just maybe, FIFA was asked to unselect Russia? Lots of businessmen were making sacrifices, as they were asked to by the Obama Administration.

Yes, I should have used the words, "not rescheduling" instead of "scheduling" or better yet "not revoking the choice of Russia" - I apologize for that.

We would all like to think that "dirty tricks" disappeared with Dick Nixon, but there is nothing "Pure and Simple" about the way the United States of America functions - perhaps you think that the FIFA officials should have scheduled speaking engagements for which they would be paid a Million dollars, to cover their tracks?

This is the BEST news I’ve read in a long time! For a governor to run on bloodlust is just horrific.

And the two senators who switched over to the governor at the last minute? Wimps!

Killing another human being is simply one of the worst things that we do here in the USA. It’s WHY we give people the death penalty because taking someone’s life is the worst crime there is. We don’t give a death penalty to someone who defrauds stock holders or for larceny or even robbing $150 million in diamonds. We give the death penalty to those who murder.. homicide.

It’s time we stopped government sanctioned homicide.

Hooray for Nebraska! Time to enter the 21st century Americans!

How is it that fraud by Wall Street that amounts to a trillion dollars at least goes unpunished, but the US is so adamant about investigating every little detail of a soccer organization??

Fishy does not begin to describe it.
You have a point, but would you rather see this corruption continue ? Regarding this statement: 'Russia is less of a danger to Western European liberties than the U.S. at this point.'  Really ?
Now if Loretta Lynch can extradite the 2022 World Cup back to America where it rightfully belongs, then we'll be in business!
